intro: Camelina sativa var. zingeri, commonly known as Zinger's camelina, is a variant of the annual herbaceous plant native to Central Asia. It is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and narrow, linear leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soil. It is often cultivated for its oil-rich seeds, which are used in both culinary and industrial applications. Due to its adaptability and low maintenance requirements, it is also valued as a cover crop in agricultural systems.
